sect1.title: Configuring &slema; to require U2F keys for local login
sect1.para: To provide more security during the local login to &slema;, you can configure two-factor authentication using the pam-u2f framework and the U2F feature on Yubikeys and Security Keys.

To set up U2F on your &slema; system, you need to associate your key to your account on &slema;. After that, configure your system to use the key. The procedure is described in the following sections.

note.title: Placing the u2f_keys to a non-default location
note.para: If you move the output file to a different directory or you choose a different file name than is the default ($HOME/.config/Yubico/u2f_keys), you need to add the path to the /etc/pam.d/login file as described in .

sect2.title: Updating the PAM configuration
sect2.para: After you have created the U2F keys configuration, you need to adjust the PAM configuration on your system.

step.screen: #%PAM-1.0 auth include common-auth account include common-account password include common-password session optional pam_keyinit.so revoke session include common-session #session optional pam_xauth.so

step.para: Add the line auth required pam_u2f.so to the file as follows:
step.screen: #%PAM-1.0 auth include common-auth auth required pam_u2f.so account include common-account password include common-password session optional pam_keyinit.so revoke session include common-session #session optional pam_xauth.so

step.para: If you placed the u2f_keys file to a different location than $HOME/.config/Yubico/u2f_keys, you need to use the authfile option in the /etc/pam.d/login PAM file as follows:
step.screen: #%PAM-1.0 auth requisite pam_nologin.so auth include common-auth auth required pam_u2f.so authfile=<PATH_TO_u2f_keys> ...
